case-studies history lessons

8.1 Amazon's Rise

  • BackgroundÔºö
    • IPO in 1997, primarily online book retail.
    • Long-term unprofitable, lost money for many years.
  • ProblemÔºö
    • Investors questioned: Was it an "internet bubble" or "future retail giant"?
  • Company ResponseÔºö
    • Persisted in reinvestment, put profits into logistics, warehousing, and AWS cloud computing.
    • Built strong supply chain moat + cloud computing new growth point.
  • Investment InsightÔºö
    • Losses ‚â† no value. Look at revenue growth in financial reports and future cash flow potential.
    • Long-term holding of quality growth stocks ‚Üí amazing returns ($10,000 in 1997 ‚Üí over $1,000,000 in 2023).

8.2 Kodak's Decline

  • BackgroundÔºö
    • Was global film giant, almost monopolized market 1970‚Äì1990.
    • Extremely high gross margins, top brand recognition.
  • ProblemÔºö
    • Digital camera technology emerged ‚Üí Kodak invented it but didn't dare promote it (worried about cannibalizing film business).
  • Company ResponseÔºö
    • Transformation failed, missed digital wave, finally bankrupt in 2012.
  • Investment InsightÔºö
    • Moats don't mean forever safe. If industry trends change, companies must innovate.
    • Industry lifecycle > individual company's will.

8.3 Nvidia's Turnaround

  • BackgroundÔºö
    • 1999‚Äì2010 mainly made graphics cards, gaming market.
    • Stock price flat long-term.
  • ProblemÔºö
    • GPU market ceiling limited, how to find new growth point?
  • Company ResponseÔºö
    • Bet on CUDA platform, used GPUs for AI training and data centers.
    • From 2016, AI demand exploded, Nvidia became "AI chip king".
  • Investment InsightÔºö
    • Technological moat + industry trend = explosive growth.
    • Investors should see how companies seize new opportunities at inflection points.

8.4 Netflix's Transformation

  • BackgroundÔºö
    • Founded 1997, initially DVD rental business.
    • Early 2000s: Competed with Blockbuster, market wasn't optimistic.
  • ProblemÔºö
    • Streaming technology emerged, DVD rental model would be obsolete.
  • Company ResponseÔºö
    • Boldly transformed to streaming platform, invested in original content.
    • Built algorithm recommendation + subscription model moat.
  • Investment InsightÔºö
    • Dare to self-revolutionize to avoid being eliminated by the times.
    • Companies that successfully transform gain new valuation premiums.

8.5 Kweichow Moutai's Moat

  • BackgroundÔºö
    • China's baijiu leader, limited production.
    • Gross margin > 90%, net margin ~50%.
  • ProblemÔºö
    • Many liquor companies, why can Moutai dominate the high-end market?
  • Company ResponseÔºö
    • Scarcity (geographic indication + unique brewing process).
    • Strong brand premium ‚Üí became "status symbol", not just a beverage.
  • Investment InsightÔºö
    • Brand moat can allow companies to maintain ultra-high margins.
    • Investors buy not the liquor, but the brand and culture.

8.6 Summary: Investment and Entrepreneurship Insights

  1. Amazon ‚Üí Look at future cash flow and revenue growth, not just profits.
  2. Kodak ‚Üí Moats can be destroyed by industry trends.
  3. Nvidia ‚Üí Technological breakthrough + industry trend = explosive returns.
  4. Netflix ‚Üí Self-revolution to sustain growth.
  5. Moutai ‚Üí The power of brand moat.

üëâ When investing, ask:

  • Does this company have a long-term moat?
  • Can it adapt to industry trends?
  • Can it transform at critical moments?

üìò Full Course Summary

  • How to Pick Good Companies: Look at fundamentals, financial statements, valuation, moats, industry trends.
  • Investment Methodology: Value investing, growth investing, index investing ‚Üí Alpha and Beta.
  • Global Markets: Three major US indices are investment benchmarks, emerging markets are more volatile.
  • Combining Entrepreneurship and Investment: Investors evaluate companies, entrepreneurs should learn to build companies in reverse.
  • Historical Cases: Long-term holding of quality companies can achieve compound miracles; ignoring trends and moats leads to company decline.
